author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Carmen Vázquez, a longtime force in the world of L.G.B.T.Q. rights, dies at 72.
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Abraham Twerski, Who Merged 12 Steps and the Torah, Dies at 90
description: A noted psychiatrist, he looked outside his Orthodox tradition to meld an eclectic menu of addiction treatments, including the A.A. idea of a “higher power.”
content: Abraham J. Twerski was an Orthodox rabbi, the descendant of several Hasidic dynasties. Yet he was also a psychiatrist and a respected authority on addiction who was drawn to the 12-step approach central to Alcoholics Anonymous, a program whose origins are Christian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Marjorie Taylor Greene and the Republican Perversion of ‘Freedom’
description: She’s playing the victim. Don’t fall for it.
content: The Republican delirium drawing the most attention is the party’s indulgence of Marjorie Taylor Greene as she turns madness into martyrdom. Mustn’t alienate the QAnon caucus! Can’t win elections without ’em, and if Democratic leaders aren’t exactly cannibals and pedophiles, well, they want higher taxes on the affluent and more Americans enrolled in Obamacare, which is pretty much the same thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Partly Backs Religious Challenge to California Virus Restrictions
description: The ruling followed a similar one in a case from New York and provided more evidence of a change in the court’s direction after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: WASHINGTON — A splintered Supreme Court on late Friday night partly lifted restrictions on religious services in California that had been prompted by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How to Help When Adolescents Have Suicidal Thoughts
description: Even when rates of suicidal ideation increase, there are ways to keep kids safe.
content: With some evidence suggesting that more adolescents have been reporting suicidal thoughts during the pandemic, experts and parents are looking for ways to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: People Want Real Change From Facebook. Its ‘Supreme Court’ Isn’t Delivering.
description: The first decisions from the new Oversight Board have been issued. The results are underwhelming.
content: Facebook’s Oversight Board, the handpicked band of outsiders charged with ruling on thorny issues at the company, handed down its first opinions after months of deliberation late last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pascale Bonnefoy and Mike Ives
title: Public Buildings Set Ablaze in Chile After Police Shoot Street Juggler
description: Protesters were outraged by the killing, which was recorded on video. Ten public offices burned to the ground, leaving a city of almost 34,000 practically without public services.
content: SANTIAGO, Chile — Demonstrators angered by the fatal police shooting of a popular street juggler set several public buildings ablaze in southern Chile Friday night, leaving a city of almost 34,000 people practically without public services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Wise
title: A flood of emotions, along with a first shot.
description: A Times editor describes getting the vaccine as a glimmer of joy during a dark and cold winter.
content: One morning this week, as I was driving 90 minutes down a highway, past frost-covered fields and bright white church steeples, I finally cried. I was on my way to get the vaccine, and after nearly a year of bottling up emotions, they were suddenly pouring out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: Pandemic’s Toll on Housing: Falling Behind, Doubling Up
description: Eviction moratoriums don’t keep arrears from piling up, and aid to renters may not reach the most vulnerable.
content: As the pandemic enters its second year, millions of renters are struggling with a loss of income and with the insecurity of not knowing how long they will have a home. Their savings depleted, they are running up credit card debt to make the rent, or accruing months of overdue payments. Families are moving in together, offsetting the cost of housing by finding others to share it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Mehlman Petrzela
title: Goodbye to the Cult of SoulCycle
description: From vaccine line-cutting to outright racism, revelations are exposing the darkness at the core of the boutique fitness craze.
content: I resisted SoulCycle, the trendy boutique fitness chain, for years. My last indoor cycling experience had been in the 1990s, when spinning was “Spinning,” and my most vivid memories were bruises from the bike seat and an instructor who looked as if he’d forgotten to shed his Lance Armstrong Halloween costume. But in 2011, I was too hugely pregnant to run or dance. One day a friend who worked at Soul, as acolytes called it, invited me along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monica Corcoran Harel
title: Smokers Might Be Lighting Up More
description: Some blame the pandemic for the stress and boredom that have led them to buy more cigarettes.
content: Maria Neuman blames Netflix. “Last night, I blistered through seven cigarettes because I was watching a movie,” said Ms. Neuman, 51, a freelance writer who lives in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles. “It’s bad enough that I started smoking again during a pandemic. Now, I’m smoking inside.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Last Undecided House Race Finally Goes to Republican, by 109 Votes
description: Claudia Tenney, a Republican from Central New York, regained a seat she had lost in 2018 after a judge ruled that her 109-vote victory was legitimate.
content: The nation’s last undecided House race came to an apparent resolution on Friday when a judge ruled that Claudia Tenney, a former Republican congresswoman in Central New York, be certified the winner, three months after Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Albert Hale, Former President of Navajo Nation, Dies at 70
description: Mr. Hale was a trailblazing lawyer and a vocal advocate for Indigenous rights and securing greater tax revenues for Arizona’s tribal nations. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: ‘Freight Train’ Storm Will Bring Up to 8 Inches of Snow to the East
description: The storm promises to create havoc for travelers on Super Bowl Sunday and be followed by single-digit temperatures, forecasters said.
content: A storm likened to a freight train — powerful and large — will bring half a foot of snow to many parts of the East Coast and New England on Sunday, just days after another storm left two or more feet of snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can My Building Mandate Vaccinations for Workers and Staff?
description: There will be plenty of legal hurdles, but some buildings are beginning to think about a future when mandatory vaccines are possible.
content: Q: Once the Covid-19 vaccine becomes more widely available, could my co-op board require building staff, like the doormen and porters, to get vaccinated? What about workers who come in periodically, like housekeepers or contractors renovating an apartment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Progressives Made a Splash. Can They Pass Bills, Too?
description: A new firm helping progressive groups highlights a dynamic of the Biden era: Many of the most influential voices in Democratic politics are also the least experienced.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Wants Harris to Have a Major Role. What It Is Hasn’t Been Defined.
description: President Biden is rarely seen without Kamala Harris, a tangible result of his efforts to treat her as an equal stakeholder. But for now he does not intend to assign her a specific portfolio.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden was rattling off a list of his priorities for a coronavirus relief bill in one of his first meetings with reporters as commander in chief when he stopped midsentence to correct himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: A Rotating Group of Intelligence Analysts Will Brief President Biden
description: Morgan Muir, who had led Mr. Biden’s first briefings in the early days of the administration, will oversee the assembly of the written President’s Daily Brief, among other responsibilities.
content: WASHINGTON — A veteran C.I.A. analyst who had led President Biden’s in-person briefings in the opening days of the administration is no longer doing so, intelligence officials said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: In Beleaguered Babylon, Doing Battle Against Time, Water and Modern Civilization
description: The ancient city of Babylon is a World Heritage Site, but it faces threats old and new. As some of its walls crumble, preservationists are fighting to preserve the past.
content: BABYLON, Iraq — Ammar al-Taee, an Iraqi archaeologist, picked up a clay panel fallen from one of the ancient walls of Babylon. Paw prints of a dog that wandered onto the drying clay more than 2,000 years ago obscure part of the cuneiform inscription — a reminder that these ruins were once a living city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Max Rivlin-Nadler
title: Migrant Families Force Biden to Confront New Border Crisis
description: In recent days, hundreds of migrant families have been released into the United States by Border Patrol agents. Thousands more are hoping for a chance to enter under looser policies.
content: LOS ANGELES — President Biden’s first immigration crisis has already begun as thousands of families have surged toward the southwestern border in recent weeks, propelled by expectations of a friendlier reception and by a change in Mexican policy that makes it harder for the United States to expel some of the migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Growing Chorus of N.B.A. Stars Boos League’s Virus Strategy
description: Giannis Antetokounmpo and Kawhi Leonard joined LeBron James in criticizing the league’s plans for an All-Star Game, while Kevin Durant questioned protocols.
content: Multiple N.B.A. stars, including Giannis Antetokounmpo, Kawhi Leonard and Kevin Durant, added their voices to the growing chorus of players criticizing the league’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic, particularly plans to hold the All-Star Game in Atlanta on March 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: HNA Was Once China’s Biggest Dealmaker. Now It Faces Bankruptcy.
description: China is tightening the reins on its economy and looking out for companies that could pose risks to China’s financial system.
content: HONG KONG — Its lenders are pushing for bankruptcy. Its chairman and co-founder has been quietly stripped of power. Nearly $10 billion of its money has been embezzled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: A New Front in the Anti-Vaccine Fight Emerges in California
description: For months, far-right activists have rallied against masks and lockdowns imposed during the coronavirus pandemic. Now some protesters have shifted their focus to the Covid-19 vaccine.
content: LOS ANGELES — An out-of-work stand-up comic originally from New Jersey. An actor and conservative podcast host dressed in a white lab coat. A gadfly who has run several unsuccessful campaigns for Congress in Los Angeles. And at least a few who had been in Washington the day of the Capitol riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Dana Rubinstein
title: How the Pandemic Left the $25 Billion Hudson Yards Eerily Deserted
description: The largest private development in U.S. history has attracted marquee companies, but is struggling with unsold luxury condos and a mall barren of shoppers.
content: When Hudson Yards opened in 2019 as the largest private development in American history, it aspired to transform Manhattan’s Far West Side with a sleek spread of ultraluxury condominiums, office towers for powerhouse companies like Facebook, and a mall with coveted international brands and restaurants by celebrity chefs like José Andrés.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Bars Trump From Receiving Intelligence Briefings, Citing ‘Erratic Behavior’
description: Mr. Biden said there was “no need” for former President Donald J. Trump to get the briefings, traditionally given to ex-presidents as a courtesy and to keep them informed if their advice is needed.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Friday that he would bar his predecessor, Donald J. Trump, from receiving intelligence briefings traditionally given to former presidents, saying that Mr. Trump could not be trusted because of his “erratic behavior” even before the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Reverses Trump Terrorist Designation for Houthis in Yemen
description: Critics of the Trump administration action said the penalties would punish the millions of starving people in Yemen more than the Houthi rebels.
content: WASHINGTON — The State Department on Friday said it would lift a terrorist designation against Houthi rebels in Yemen that the Trump administration had issued in its final days, revoking penalties that aides to President Biden worried would bring more pain to millions of starving people than to the rebels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Lawsuits Take the Lead in Fight Against Disinformation
description: Defamation cases have made waves across an uneasy right-wing media landscape, from Fox to Newsmax.
content: In just a few weeks, lawsuits and legal threats from a pair of obscure election technology companies have achieved what years of advertising boycotts, public pressure campaigns and liberal outrage could not: curbing the flow of misinformation in right-wing media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Immunization Expert Accuses C.D.C. and Deloitte of Stealing Her Idea
description: The Trump administration awarded a no-bid contract to Deloitte to develop software to track vaccinations, but the system has flaws. A competitor claims the C.D.C. and the company stole her intellectual property.
content: WASHINGTON — Last spring, when coronavirus vaccines were just a glimmer of hope, the Trump administration awarded the first of two no-bid contracts worth up to $44 million to a national consulting firm to help patients register to be immunized and states collect detailed data on vaccine recipients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: How the United States Lost to Hackers
description: America’s biggest vulnerability in cyberwarfare is hubris.
content: If ever there was a sign the United States was losing control of information warfare, of its own warriors, it was the moment one of its own, a young American contractor, saw first lady Michelle Obama’s emails pop up on his screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg
title: Pushing QAnon and Stolen Election Lies, Flynn Re-emerges
description: Recast by President Trump’s most ardent supporters as a MAGA martyr, Michael T. Flynn has embraced his role as the man who spent four years unjustly ensnared in the Russia investigation.
content: In Washington’s respectable circles, Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, is a discredited and dishonored ex-general, a once-esteemed military intelligence officer who went off the rails ideologically and then was fired a mere 24 days into the Trump administration for lying to the F.B.I. about contacts with the Russian ambassador.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Task Ahead for Biden on Climate
description: The new president has shown a welcome interest in combating climate change. But more will need to be done.
content: After four years of scorn, the issue of climate change has risen near the top of the American political agenda, where it deserves to be and where, even accounting for the efforts of Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, it had never been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Toddler Talk
description: Christina Iverson and a new constructor, Katie Hale, give little kids (and the rest of us) a mwah! of a Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This post might be a little bit short and sweet because here in rural Queens, N.Y., where the internet tubes get flooded from time to time, I am tethered to my phone like a pioneer with a rope tied to the barn during a blizzard. Anyway! I’m lucky that our two constructors have a back story that’s as charming as their collaboration; this grid is really lighthearted and lovely, not too easy but great for a range of Sunday solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Luke Broadwater
title: With Economy in ‘Crisis,’ Biden Is Ready to Bypass G.O.P. on Stimulus
description: President Biden said the economy was in trouble and warned Republicans that he would move ahead with a $1.9 trillion aid package with or without their support.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, spurred on by a lackluster January jobs report and Democratic support for his $1.9 trillion economic aid proposal, said on Friday that the economy was in need of urgent help and that Republicans should either get on board with a robust stimulus package or expect his plan to pass without their support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: To Hear America’s Mothers, We Let Them Scream
description: In a special report, Times journalists ventured into the homes of three working parents as they navigated the daily grind of the pandemic. They also gave mothers an outlet to vent.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Newcastle, Leeds and the Importance of Being … Something
description: Wandering about without a plan inspires neither affection nor success. So why do so many clubs still do it?
content: NEWCASTLE, England — The sound system at St James’s Park crackled into life just as the whistle blew and the players took the knee, as they have done for every Premier League game since the spring. The announcement was brief and sweet, an unexpected relic of days past: “Enjoy the game.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: I.C.C. Rules It Has Jurisdiction to Examine Possible Israel War Crimes
description: The International Criminal Court on Friday said it has the authority to investigate alleged crimes in the occupied territories, in a ruling condemned by Israel and praised by Palestinians.
content: JERUSALEM — The International Criminal Court on Friday determined that it has jurisdiction over the territories occupied by Israel in 1967, despite Israel’s insistence to the contrary, opening the way for an inquiry into allegations of Israeli, and Palestinian, war crimes in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Is your vaccine card selfie a gift for scammers? Maybe.
description: So you finally got a Covid-19 vaccine. Relieved, you take a photograph of your vaccination card, showing your name and birth date and which vaccine you had, and publish it on social media.
content: So you finally got a Covid-19 vaccine. Relieved, you take a photograph of your vaccination card, showing your name and birth date and which vaccine you had, and publish it on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Russia Casts Out Diplomats Over Navalny Protests
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 6, 2021.
content: “The iron doors slam shut behind me with a deafening clang, but I feel like a free man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni, Lauren Hirsch and Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Money in Politics, One Month Later
description: Since the Capitol riot, companies have re-evaluated their political donations. Will this be a turning point or a momentary blip?
content: It’s been one month since a mob stormed the Capitol, which led to soul-searching about the influence of money in politics (among other things). The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, and today we look at how corporate cash became such a feature of the system, what’s changed since the riot and what it means for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Yurek and Bob Keefe
title: This Climate Deal Is Good for Earth and the Economy
description: More than 100 nations have approved an accord phasing down a planet-warming coolant. The U.S. isn’t among them.
content: Tucked into the huge omnibus spending package that President Trump signed before leaving office was something out of sync with his administration’s regressive climate agenda: Legislation that authorized a phase-down in the production and use of heat-trapping chemical coolants known as hydrofluorocarbons.
source.name: The New York Times

title: This Sugar Cookie Bar Is Worth the Hype
description: And 19 other eye-catching recipes to save immediately.
content: This week, nothing caught our readers’ attention quite like these delightful sugar cookie bars (above), with their blush tops and cheery sprinkles. They’re sure to brighten even the dreariest day. If that’s not your thing, maybe you’d like to add a tres leches cake to the to-do list. Or, if you’re more of a savory baker, consider a crispy mushroom focaccia. Whatever your tastes, you’re sure to find something to love in our collection of the 20 most popular recipes from the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Tiffany Hsu
title: Three false claims about the election made in Mike Lindell’s new film.
description: One America News ran an extensive disclaimer before the broadcast.
content: The 2020 presidential election was three months ago, but one of the biggest backers of the false theory that it was rigged against former President Donald J. Trump has not given up his hope of overturning the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monica Corcoran Harel
title: Reaching for that pack of smokes? You aren’t the only one.
description: Lots of people seem to be smoking again or more during the pandemic, if anecdotal evidence and preliminary sales figures for tobacco products are any measure.
content: Lots of people seem to be smoking again or more during the pandemic, if anecdotal evidence and preliminary sales figures for tobacco products are any measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: At the Super Bowl, Antonio Brown Tries to Move On. Many Cannot.
description: The Buccaneers receiver has been one of the most electrifying players in the N.F.L., but he is facing accusations of sexual assault and harassment.
content: Get over it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter, Najim Rahim and Kiana Hayeri
title: In Afghanistan, a Booming Kidney Trade Preys on the Poor
description: Widespread poverty and an ambitious private hospital are helping to fuel an illegal market — a portal to new misery for the country’s most vulnerable.
content: HERAT, Afghanistan — Amid the bustle of beggars and patients outside the crowded hospital here, there are sellers and buyers, casting wary eyes at one another: The poor, seeking cash for their vital organs, and the gravely ill or their surrogates, looking to buy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Ugly Secrets Behind the Costco Chicken
description: An investigator went under cover and brought back disturbing video from a farm growing those famous birds.
content: Probably like many of you, I think of Costco as an enlightened company exemplifying capitalism that works. One ranking listed it as the No. 1 company to work at in terms of pay and benefits — a prime example of a business that is both profitable and humane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: African-American Icons
description: Will Shortz presents a list of notable names, and a hidden quotation
content: VARIETY PUZZLE — This word search is a neat departure from our regular rotation — I haven't solved one of these for many years, although now that I look there are tons available online and the digital environment is nice for this kind of puzzle. This is a who’s who quiz of 22 prominent Black figures in history; use the clues to figure out who you’re looking for, circle them in the letter set, then read the leftover letters for the coup de grâce, a quotation by Muhammad Ali (an unexpected one, for this solver).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: To Fight or Hide: Fear Grips Myanmar With Military Back in Charge
description: Dozens of arrests, beatings by mysterious thugs and telecommunication cutoffs are the new reality across the country. But civil disobedience defiantly persists.
content: The red balloons rose over an anxious city. They floated by the hundreds above the golden spire of Sule Pagoda in Yangon, the commercial capital of Myanmar, and drifted over an avenue where, more than a dozen years ago, soldiers shot citizens marching peacefully for democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Popkin
title: Invasive Insects and Diseases Are Killing Our Forests
description: America wasn’t ready for the pandemic. And it isn’t ready for the next contagion to strike our woodlands.
content: It’s not just humans. Trees also suffer plagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize? Wait Until You Receive It to Brag
description: Thousands of people, including university professors, can submit nominations. Hundreds are submitted per year.
content: Unlike major Hollywood awards shows, where it really is an honor just to be nominated, the Nobel Peace Prize accepts submissions from a potential pool of thousands of nominators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: The Great Pandemic Wedding Boom
description: Scary, stressful times tend to lead to increased marriage rates. The coronavirus pandemic is no different.
content: If the world is ending, who do you want by your side?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: For Buttigieg, ‘Generational’ Transportation Change May Not Be Easy, Experts Say
description: The new secretary has stirred excitement among transportation experts, but they warn that deep institutional change is likely to remain difficult.
content: WASHINGTON — Now that Pete Buttigieg is secretary of transportation, he faces a challenge: delivering on his promises of infrastructure overhaul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: A no-bid contract to track vaccinations leads to frustration and a cease-and-desist letter.
description: Last spring, when coronavirus vaccines were just a glimmer of hope, the Trump administration awarded the first of two no-bid contracts worth up to $44 million to a national consulting firm to help patients register to be immunized and states collect detailed data on vaccine recipients.
content: Last spring, when coronavirus vaccines were just a glimmer of hope, the Trump administration awarded the first of two no-bid contracts worth up to $44 million to a national consulting firm to help patients register to be immunized and states collect detailed data on vaccine recipients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Herrera
title: Remember: What You Do Is Not Who You Are
description: The line between our personal lives and our work lives has all but disappeared. Make the effort to redraw it.
content: One of the best pieces of career advice I’ve ever gotten was to think of jobs as verbs, rather than nouns. So, for example: I do journalism, rather than I’m a journalist. Or: I do youth education, rather than I’m a teacher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why the U.S. Needs the Romney Family Plan
description: America needs more babies. Public policy alone cannot deliver them, but it can help.
content: Family policy, the way that America supports (or doesn’t) parenthood and child rearing, has always presented the best opportunity for serious bipartisanship in Joe Biden’s presidency. It’s an issue with real overlap between the left and right: Feminists and social conservatives, left-wing antipoverty activists and right-wing pro-natalists all agree that it’s too hard to raise kids in America today. And it’s an issue where the relevant interest group, the American family, isn’t a partisan force or a pre-mobilized constituency — which is usually a weakness for its interests, but in a polarized moment might actually make legislation easier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Feud Between Hollywood Agents and TV Writers Comes to an End
description: A fight over conflict-of-interest claims began nearly two years ago. William Morris Endeavor was the last major agency to reach a new agreement.
content: A bitter feud pitting thousands of movie and television screenwriters against the major Hollywood talent agencies came to an end on Friday, nearly two years after it had begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Ron DePasquale
title: They died within hours of each other early in the pandemic. Their countries then went down two very different roads.
description: Soon after the death of a doctor who was one of the first to warn publicly about the coronavirus, China abruptly reversed course. The United States took a very different path after what would be its first confirmed death of the pandemic.
content: One day. Two deaths. A year later, despite the hundreds of thousands of deaths that followed, the loss of two people — one in China and one in the United States — still reverberates in two countries where the pandemic took drastically different paths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Exiled From Committees, Greene Says She Is ‘Freed’ to Push Republicans to the Right
description: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene warned that the House’s vote only left her with more time to insist on Republicans’ allegiance to former President Donald J. Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — One day after the House voted to banish her from congressional committees, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene sent a defiant message to both parties on Friday, warning that the punishment had only “freed” her to press Republicans further to the right and insist on their allegiance to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Is Your Vaccine Card Selfie a Gift for Scammers? Maybe
description: You finally got your vaccine, and you’re excited to share the proof. Here’s why that may not be a good idea, and what you can do instead.
content: So you finally got a Covid-19 vaccine. Relieved, you take a photograph of your vaccination card, showing your name and birth date and which vaccine you had, and publish it on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Frank Shankwitz, a Founder of Make-a-Wish, Is Dead at 77
description: A state highway patrolman in Arizona, he helped a terminally ill boy become a motorcycle cop and then came up with a plan to help more children realize their dreams.
content: Frank Shankwitz, an Arizona Highway Patrol officer who, after helping a terminally ill boy realize his dream of becoming a motorcycle cop, co-founded the Make-a-Wish Foundation and served as its first president, died on Jan. 24 at his home in Prescott, Ariz. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Big Scoop
description: Kameron Austin Collins ends our week with a flourish.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — February is Black History Month, and the puzzles for Monday through Saturday this week were made by Black constructors. In this article, the editorial director for New York Times Games, Everdeen Mason, discusses the week’s puzzles in the context of Black History Month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Kelly
title: ‘Bridgerton’ Is Just the Beginning
description: In this time of our confinement, fans of period clothing are having a lot of fun on social media.
content: It’s a world of corsets, stays and chemises. Of weskits, bum rolls, breeches and hoop panniers. For actors, wearing period costume has long meant literally stepping into the past: lacing soft modern flesh into antique shapes and learning how to use the toilet without peeling off multiple layers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Kevin Draper
title: Britt Reid, a Chiefs Assistant Coach, Is Involved in a Car Crash
description: The team released a statement confirming that Reid, the son of Kansas City’s head coach, Andy Reid, had been in an accident but provided no other details.
content: Britt Reid, the outside linebackers coach for the Kansas City Chiefs and the son of the head coach, Andy Reid, was in an automobile crash on Thursday night, the team said in a statement Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Watch This Billion-Year Journey of Earth’s Tectonic Plates
description: A new simulation offers a different view of how the continents we live on drifted into their current configuration.
content: Unlike on every other rocky planet in the solar system, Earth’s surface is a giant jigsaw puzzle whose pieces are constantly on the move. Each puzzle piece is a tectonic plate, tremendous tartines made of the planet’s crust and a rigid slice of the underlying, squidgy-but-solid mantle. These plates move around at the same rate that your fingernails grow, bumping into, sliding next to and tumbling under and over each other — and in doing so, they sculpt the face of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 6, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 6, 2021.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a boost given to companies endangered by the pandemic by rising stock prices described incorrectly one of the ways that companies can borrow money. Borrowing involves selling bonds to investors, not equity.
source.name: The New York Times
